metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State (M/s Nandoo Ram Khedan Lal)

facts.text: M/s Nandoo Ram Khedan Lal (complainants) carry on business in Varanasi in chewing tobacco marketed under trade-mark 'Titli (butterfly)' with label showing three butterflies on yellow-green background and legend 'Titli' in Devnagari and English.

Appellant carries on business in chewing tobacco and commenced marketing goods under name 'Titli (partridge)' with label showing four butterflies on leaf-green background and legend 'Titli' in Devnagari and English. Colour schemes of butterflies substantially similar.
Some time before 1955, appellant started marketing goods under trade-mark 'Titli'; no evidence about general get-up of label at that time.

On January 6, 1955, complainants wrote to appellant claiming sole proprietorship of 'Titli' brand, registered trade-mark, alleging appellant's criminal intention in using and copying it on inferior tobacco, passing off as their product, calling upon him to desist.

Appellant replied denying complainants' sole proprietorship, claiming he had not used 'Titli' on his goods, had marketed under 'Titli' for many years, and accused complainants of passing off their product as his.
No steps taken by complainants against appellant after correspondence until November 1960.
In November 1960, complainants informed police that appellant infringed trade-mark by marketing under mark calculated to deceive purchasers.

Appellant charged before Magistrate 1st Class, Varanasi, with being on November 25, 1960, in possession of counterfeit labels usable to pass off tobacco tins as goods of complainants bearing 'Titli' trade-mark, and possession for sale of tobacco tins bearing counterfeit 'Titli' trade-mark.
Police submitted charge-sheet against appellant for offences under s.78 r/w s.77 and s.79 of Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958, lodged in Magistrate's court on March 22, 1961.

Trial Magistrate convicted appellant under s.78 r/w s.77 and s.79, sentenced to simple imprisonment for three months each, to run consecutively; observed close resemblance between labels, illiterate users likely deceived by pictorial device.
Sessions Court, Varanasi, set aside conviction and acquitted appellant on ground prosecution barred by s.92 of the Act.
Allahabad High Court set aside acquittal, restored conviction, reduced sentence to fine of Rs.1,000/- on each charge; agreed with Magistrate and Sessions Judge on resemblance and deception.
High Court granted certificate under Art.134 Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether prosecution was barred by s.92 of Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958, given knowledge of infringement since 1955.
Whether there was acquiescence by complainants justifying inference of assent to appellant's use of trade-mark.
Whether labels substantially similar causing deception, especially to illiterate purchasers.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution barred by s.92 as complainants admitted learning of infringement in 1955, proceedings started November 1960 exceed limitation; interpret as from first discovery.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.92 Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958; Ruppell v. Ponnusami Jevan; Dau Dayal v. State of Uttar Pradesh

petitioner_arguments.text: Acquiescence by complainants after 1955 letter and reply, no steps until 1960, inferring assent to use of trade-mark.

respondent_arguments.text: Offences committed on November 25, 1960; charge-sheet March 22, 1961 within limitation under s.92 from commission or discovery of offence charged.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.92 Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958

court_reasoning.text: No substantial argument to differ from lower courts on close resemblance of labels and likelihood of deception to illiterate majority users by pictorial device.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trial Magistrate, Sessions Judge, High Court agreed on resemblance and deception.

court_reasoning.text: s.92 bars prosecution after 3 years from commission of offence charged or 2 years from discovery thereof by prosecutor, whichever first; not from first discovery or first infringement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature deliberately omitted 'first'; applies to offence charged on Nov 25, 1960, discovered Nov 1960.

court_reasoning.text: Departure from s.15 Merchandise Marks Act 1889; Ruppell case interpreted old s.15 as from first discovery if continuing, but s.92 changes to offence charged; not called to decide correctness of Ruppell.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dau Dayal incorporated Ruppell excerpt illustratively, not approving fully; Abdulsatar overruled by Emperor v. Chhotalal.

holdings.text: Prosecution not barred by s.92; limitation runs from commission or discovery of offence charged, not first infringement or discovery.
Labels substantially similar, likely to deceive illiterate purchasers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ruppell v. Ponnusami Jevan and Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Interpreted s.15 Merchandise Marks Act 1889 as limitation from first discovery if continuing offence; not applicable to s.92 of 1958 Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dau Dayal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Quoted Ruppell illustratively on general tenor of s.15, rejected limitation plea in different context.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdulsatar Khan Kamruddin Khan v. Ratanlal-Kishenlal
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Ruppell on s.15, time from first instance if continuing.
Overruled Abdulsatar; under s.15, limitation from date of offence charged.

statutes_cited.name: Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of possession of counterfeit trade marks and labels; s.92 limitation provision applied to hold prosecution not barred.

statutes_cited.name: Merchandise Marks Act, 1889
statutes_cited.relevance: Predecessor provision compared and distinguished from s.92 of 1958 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate granted for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court order restoring conviction under ss.78 r/w 77 and 79 of Trade and Merchandise Marks Act 1958, rejecting pleas of limitation under s.92 and acquiescence; no change to sentence of Rs.1,000 fine each.

key_quotes.text: No prosecution for an offence under this Act shall be commenced after the expiration of three years next after the commission of the offence charged, or two years after the discovery thereof by the prosecutor, whichever expiration first happens.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting s.92, emphasizing 'offence charged' not first discovery.

key_quotes.text: The Legislature has deliberately not used those expressions [first discovery, first infringement], and there is no warrant for substituting them in the section.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: a vast majority of users of such tobacco being illiterate were likely to be carried away by a pictorial device of Titli (butterfly) since they were incapable of reading and understanding the descriptions.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for finding deception, upheld from lower courts.
